item.title: Carney to Fast-Track ‘Nation-Building’ Projects Through Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.
item.dc:creator: Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister

item.title: ICE derrocha en envío de migrantes a remotos centros de detención
item.description: El aumento del costo del traslado de inmigrantes por parte del ICE a través del país impacta a los contribuyentes estadounidenses y perjudica las posibilidades de los detenidos de ganar sus casos judiciales.
item.dc:creator: Leon Yin, Elena Mejia, Rachel Adams-Heard, Polly Mosendz

item.title: Zelenskiy May Meet Trump on Sidelines of G-7 Summit, Aide Says
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and US President Donald Trump may meet on the sidelines of this month’s Group of Seven summit in Canada, Zelenskiy’s chief of staff Andriy Yermak said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, left, and Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, outside the West Wing of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 28, 2025. Zelenskiy is meeting with Trump to discuss a deal that would allow the US to share in Ukraine's natural resources, hoping to start a discussion on security guarantees.

item.title: Senators Ask Housing Finance Agency to Pause Plans to Privatize Fannie, Freddie
item.description: A group of Democratic senators, including Elizabeth Warren and Chuck Schumer, asked the director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency to pause any efforts to privatize mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: The Freddie Mac headquarters in Mclean, Virginia, US, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. The head of the US Federal Housing Finance Agency on Tuesday ordered to end Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac programs intended to support first-time homebuyers by providing down payments and closing cost assistance.

item.title: Court Fight Over Trump Ending a Tariff Exemption Goes Forward
item.description: A court fight over President Donald Trump’s decision to end a US policy that exempted small-value packages from China from tariffs is moving ahead over the administration’s opposition.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Packages at a sorting center in Beijing.

item.title: What Trump’s FEMA Cuts Mean for Hurricane Season
item.description: The nation’s top agency for response and recovery work has endured significant upheaval since Trump’s return to the White House, and now Atlantic hurricane season is underway.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Rosenthal, Zahra Hirji

media:content.media:description: US Army soldiers offload food and water provided by FEMA from a helicopter during recovery efforts after Hurricane Maria in Utuado, Puerto Rico, in 2017.

item.title: Macron’s Approval Rating Rises Slightly to 29%, Ifop Poll Shows
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron’s approval rating has increased by 1 point to 29%, according to a poll by Ifop for Ouest France newspaper published on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Che

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president.

item.title: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Allow Education Department Purge
item.description: President Donald Trump asked the US Supreme Court to let him resume dismantling the Department of Education, seeking to lift a lower court order that requires the reinstatement of as many as 1,400 workers.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: The US Department of Education headquarters in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Modi to Attend G-7 Summit in Canada in Sign of Warming Ties
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will be attending the Canada-hosted Group of Seven summit later this month as ties between the two nations improve.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: African Panel Challenges Fitch’s Afreximbank Ratings Downgrade
item.description: An African Union-backed panel challenged Fitch Ratings to review its downgrade of the African Export-Import Bank’s rating, questioning the company’s classification of loans to three countries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Benedict Okey Oramah, President and Chairman of the Board of Directors for Afreximbank.

item.title: Republicans Push Musk Aside as Trump Tax Bill Barrels Forward
item.description: Congressional Republicans are siding with Donald Trump in the messy divorce between the president and Elon Musk, an optimistic sign for eventual passage of a tax cut bill at the root of the two billionaires’ public feud.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson

item.title: Rifles, Stun Grenades, Armored Trucks in ICE Raids Spur Tensions
item.description: The Trump administration is intensifying efforts to round up migrants. It’s also doing so with increasingly aggressive tactics.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: ICE agents execute a criminal search warrant at Buona Forchetta in San Diego on May 30.

item.title: Trump Pressures Fed’s Powell to Cut Rates ‘A Full Point’
item.description: President Donald Trump urged the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by a full percentage point, intensifying his pressure campaign against Chair Jerome Powell.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Federal Reserve IF 75TH Anniversary Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. US President Donald Trump pushed Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president's inauguration last week, the White House said.

item.title: Trump Is Holding Back From Calling Out China Over Russia War Aid
item.description: President Donald Trump is holding back from pushing China to halt support for Russia’s war machine as he focuses on other issues in the relationship with its biggest geopolitical rival, according to US and European officials familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a meeting with Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Relations between Washington and Berlin are tense amid issues ranging from trade imbalances to support for Kyiv.

item.title: Israel’s US Broker Sells Record Debt for Nation During Gaza War
item.description: Israel has raised a record $5 billion through its US-based broker dealer, Israel Bonds, since the start of the war with Hamas, boosting its ability to finance the 20-month ongoing conflict.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Israeli tanks near Israel's border with the Gaza Srip.

item.title: Musk Blinks First in Trump Feud That Cost Him $34 Billion
item.description: When Elon Musk and Donald Trump joined forces during the presidential campaign, there was always a question over how long their alliance would last and who would prevail if it didn’t work out.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Josh Wingrove, Kate Sullivan, Derek Wallbank

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Elon Musk Photographer: Anna Moneymaker, Allison Robbert/Getty Images

item.title: Harvard’s Battle With Trump Reignites School Pride Among Alumni
item.description: Jessica Tang has two degrees from Harvard University but barely donated directly to the school in two decades as an alumnus. She’s even publicly criticized Harvard’s labor practices.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: The Widener Library on the Harvard Campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Trump Aides Signal He’s Moving on From Musk Feud But May Get Rid of His Tesla
item.description: The White House is signaling that President Donald Trump intends to move on from his acrimonious fallout with billionaire Elon Musk, focusing on securing passage of his signature tax and spending bill and other economic policies.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks during a news conference with Elon Musk in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 30.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Yunus Announces Plan to Hold Election in April 2026
item.description: Bangladesh’s interim leader Muhammad Yunus has announced that the next national election will be held in the first half of April 2026, narrowing the timeline from his earlier range of December to June and setting a clear target for the return to an elected government in the South Asian nation.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Muhammad Yunus

item.title: Harvard Sues Over Trump Barring Foreign Students’ US Entry
item.description: Harvard University sued to stop the Trump administration from barring its international students’ entrance to the US, adding to a high-stakes legal battle between the government and the school.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Janet Lorin, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusett.

item.title: Switzerland Pledges $6 Million Support for Glacier-Hit Village
item.description: The Swiss government is proposing to give 5 million francs ($6 million) to the Alpine village of Blatten that was destroyed by a wave of rock and ice last week.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: The Swiss village of Blatten following the collapse of a glacier, on May 29.

item.title: Trump-Harvard Spat Roils US Campuses With Visas Under Threat
item.description: Lately, Wesleyan University’s Michael Roth has started making a habit of checking in with his dean of admissions more often. He’s worried about their international students — and whether any have opted not to enroll.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Francesca Maglione

media:content.media:description: A student in front of the Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Library on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Netherlands to Vote on October 29 After Government Falls
item.description: The Netherlands will hold a general election on October 29 after far-right leader Geert Wilders pulled his Freedom Party out of the Dutch government earlier this week.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Hughes-Morgan

media:content.media:description: Geert Wilders attends a debate at the House of Representatives in The Hague on June 4. Photographer: REMKO DE WAAL/AFP

item.title: Dutch Central Bank Warns Government Collapse Will Hit Economy
item.description: The fall of the Dutch coalition will negatively impact investment and consumption, according to the country’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Sarah Jacob

media:content.media:description: A market stall in Amsterdam, Netherlands.

item.title: French Socialist Faure Reelected as Party Head by Narrow Margin
item.description: French Socialist Olivier Faure was reelected as head of the party in a narrow ballot win, signaling the group may be less willing to join no-confidence motions likely to be filed against Prime Minister Francois Bayrou during crucial budget negotiations over the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Olivier Faure Photographer: Bastien Ohier/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Merz Pledges New Bid With France to End Capital-Markets Impasse
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said he’ll launch a new push with France to try to break a deadlock on a decade-old European Union effort to deepen the bloc’s capital markets and improve access to funding for companies.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz at The Family Business Days 2025 event in Berlin, on June 6. Photographer: Kay Nietfeld/dpa/AP Photo

item.title: Musk Blinks First in MAGA Cockfight With Trump
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Flavia Krause-Jackson

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Elon Musk speak before departing the White House on March 14. Photographer: Roberto Schmidt/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Reform UK’s Momentum Stalled by Departures, By-Election Defeat
item.description: Nigel Farage’s recent run of political success stalled after his insurgent Reform UK suffered a pair of high-profile departures and came third in a Scottish election that it had hoped might prove its broader appeal.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Reform UK party chairman Zia Yusuf Photographer: Ben Stansall/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: The SEC Pinned Its Hack on a Few Hapless Day Traders. The Full Story Is Far More Troubling
item.description: When a notorious gang of Ukrainian cybercriminals hit a crucial database, the regulator quickly downplayed the breach. One of the hackers says the system is still a soft target.
item.dc:creator: Liam Vaughan

item.title: Xi Bets Trump Detente Will Lead to Future Wins on Chips, Tariffs
item.description: In the early hours of Wednesday, Donald Trump declared that Xi Jinping was “VERY TOUGH, AND EXTREMELY HARD TO MAKE A DEAL WITH!!!” Some 36 hours later, the US leader said he got what he wanted: A commitment to restore the flow of rare earth magnets.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Katia Dmitrieva, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping Photographer: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Pool/AFP/Getty Images
